channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: From Rockets to Ball Bearings, Pentagon Struggles to Feed War Machine
item.description: The flow of arms to Ukraine has exposed a worrisome lack of production capacity in the United States that has its roots in the end of the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Rachel Woolf for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Air Force technology expo in Aurora, Colo., this month. Major contractors like Lockheed Martin are looking across the United States to bring on new suppliers for missile programs.

item.title: A Refuge for Russians and Ukrainians, Bali Rethinks Its Open-Door Policy
item.description: After multiple accounts of tourists behaving badly, its governor wants Russia and Ukraine to lose access to Indonesia’s visa-on-arrival program.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Nyimas Laula for The New York Times
item.media:description: Echo Beach in Bali, Indonesia. Bali residents have found themselves at odds with the practices of some of the Ukrainians and Russians who’ve fled their home countries for refuge in Bali.

item.title: G.O.P. Demands on Prosecutor in Trump Case Test Limits of Oversight Power
item.description: The Manhattan district attorney is resisting efforts by House Republicans to compel him to provide information about the hush money inquiry, setting up a potential legal showdown.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios/The New York Times
item.media:description: Legal battles about the oversight authority of Congress were common during the tumultuous presidency of Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Trump Plans Rally in Waco During Anniversary of Branch Davidian Standoff
item.description: Thirty years ago, a fiery federal raid on a doomsday sect turned the city into a symbol of government overreach. Donald Trump will speak there on Saturday, and some supporters — and critics — say it’s no accident.
item.dc:creator: Charles Homans
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The chapel at Mount Carmel, near Waco, Tex., the site of the former compound of the Branch Davidian sect.

item.title: Trump, Escalating Attacks, Raises Specter of Violence if He Is Charged
item.description: In an overnight post, the former president stepped up his attacks on the Manhattan district attorney, Alvin Bragg, and warned of “potential death and destruction” if he is indicted.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios/The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump, who is again campaigning for the White House, has called the investigation a politically motivated “witch hunt.”

item.title: In Held v. Montana, Young People Sue Montana Over Use of Fossil Fuels
item.description: Sixteen young Montanans have sued their state, arguing that its support of fossil fuels violates the state Constitution.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Matthew Hamon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Badge, left, and Lander Busse, teenage plaintiffs in a lawsuit against the state of Montana saying it violated the state Constitution that guarantees “the right to a clean and healthful environment.”

item.title: Rahul Gandhi Disqualified From Lok Sabha After Conviction
item.description: The expulsion of Rahul Gandhi is a devastating blow to the once-powerful Indian National Congress party. He and several other politicians are now in jeopardy through India’s legal system.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Alex Travelli
item.media:credit: Adnan Abidi/Reuters
item.media:description: Rahul Gandhi, the leader of the Indian National Congress Party, arriving at the New Delhi airport after his court appearance in Surat, India, on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Air Defenses ‘Not Fully Operational’ Before Strike Killed American in Syria, Officials Say
item.description: American officials are investigating why the system was not fully operational and what difference that made in defending the coalition military base in northeast Syria.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III ordered airstrikes against facilities in eastern Syria used by groups affiliated with Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps.

item.title: Famed Antiwar Protester Was Once Cog in Russia’s Propaganda Machine
item.description: For 20 years, Marina Ovsyannikova worked for Russian state TV. What compelled her, shortly after Ukraine was invaded, to storm a live broadcast and tell viewers they were being lied to?
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: Garden State’s Basketball Talent Blooms in N.C.A.A. Tournament
item.description: Whether it’s teams like Princeton and Fairleigh Dickinson pulling off upsets or standout performances from players, New Jersey’s imprint has been all over the Division I men’s basketball tournament.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.category: St Anthony High School (Jersey City, NJ)
item.media:credit: Getty Images/iStockphoto; USA Today Sports; Associated Press; Illustration by Elijah Walker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Zach Martini, left, has helped 15th-seeded Princeton reach the round of 16, while other New Jersey players like Jahvon Quinerly of Alabama, middle, and Isaiah Wong of Miami have found success outside the state.

item.title: 40 Years After Phi Slama Jama, There’s Hope in Houston for a Better Finish
item.description: The 1982-83 Houston Cougars, a sensation nicknamed Phi Slama Jama, lost the N.C.A.A. men’s title game to North Carolina State on a dunk in the final moments.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Houston earned a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. Division I men’s basketball tournament for the first time since 1983, when the team reached the championship game.

item.title: Thursday March Madness: Kansas State Tops Michigan State in Overtime
item.description: Markquis Nowell led the Wildcats with 20 rebounds and 19 assists, which set a record for an N.C.A.A. tournament game. In another exciting finish, Gonzaga beat U.C.L.A. in the final seconds.
item.dc:creator: Adam Zagoria and Scott Miller
item.media:credit: Brad Penner/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Markquis Nowell scored 20 points and recorded 19 rebounds against Michigan State.

item.title: China Denies Pressuring Companies Like TikTok to Spy on Users
item.description: China’s foreign ministry rebuffed claims made by U.S. lawmakers at a hearing on Thursday that TikTok could be a tool of surveillance for the Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Shou Chew, the chief executive of TikTok, testifying before the House Energy and Commerce Committee in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: TikTok’s C.E.O. Struggles to Make his Case in Washington
item.description: Lawmakers interrogated Shou Chew over the video app’s ties to the Chinese government in a hearing that suggests the company’s problems are far from over.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images
item.media:description: All eyes on Shou Chew.

item.title: Florida Bill Would Shield DeSantis’s Travel Records
item.description: A bill advanced by state legislators would exempt the governor, as well as other officials, their families and staff members, from having records of their trips released to the public.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: As he lays the groundwork to run for president, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has faced mounting questions about his use of state resources as well as his reliance on donors’ planes.

item.title: What’s Fueling Mushroom Mania in Décor?
item.description: As mushrooms become more prominent in nearly all spheres of modern life — including wellness, pop culture and cuisine — they’re also becoming sought-after motifs in interior design.
item.dc:creator: Anna Kodé
item.media:credit: Halkin Mason for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jayna Roy designed a mushroom-themed nursery for her daughter.

item.title: Don’t Be Fooled. Ron DeSantis Is a Bush-Cheney Republican.
item.description: It is simply wrong to attribute the pathologies of today’s Republican Party to the influence of Donald Trump alone.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times

item.title: Yuval Harari on Threats to Humanity Posed by A.I.
item.description: In games like chess, no human can hope to beat a computer. What happens when the same thing occurs in art, politics and even religion?
item.dc:creator: Yuval Harari, Tristan Harris and Aza Raskin
item.media:credit: Illustration by Zisiga Mukulu/The New York Times; photograph by Jonathan Knowles/Getty Images

item.title: The Man Who Leaked the Pentagon Papers Is Scared
item.description: The whistle-blower Daniel Ellsberg has never run out of secrets.
item.dc:creator: Alex Kingsbury
item.media:credit: Andres Gonzalez for The New York Times

item.title: This Column Is Dedicated to Silicon Valley Venture Capitalists
item.description: The tech industry is far from perfect, but it remains essential to America’s future.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo
item.media:credit: Noah Berger/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Should the Government Pay for Your Bad Climate Decisions?
item.description: As climate change becomes a health risk, the U.S. government has warned it will reassess spending priorities.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Carlos Prieto, Michael Simon Johnson, Rob Szypko, Anita Badejo, Patricia Willens, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden speaking in Philadelphia in March as he releases his budget proposal for the 2024 fiscal year.

item.title: Free Speech (or Not) at Stanford
item.description: A federal judge spoke at Stanford Law School. Chaos ensued.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Ben Margot/Associated Press
item.media:description: Stanford University.

item.title: Cleaner Air Helps Everyone. It Helps Black Communities a Lot.
item.description: A new study quantified the benefits of pollution reduction in terms of race and class.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: St. James, La., one of several Mississippi River towns dotted by chemical plants and oil refineries.

item.title: ‘Hotel Rwanda’ Hero, Paul Rusesabagina, to Be Released From Prison
item.description: Paul Rusesabagina, whose story inspired a Hollywood movie, was kidnapped by the Rwandan government and jailed. In a deal brokered by the U.S. and Qatar, he is to be set free.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Cyril Ndegeya for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paul Rusesabagina leaving a court hearing in Kigali, Rwanda, in 2020. His release will end two and a half years in captivity.

item.title: California’s Plan for Cheaper Insulin Collides With Big Pharma’s Price Cuts
item.description: The state awarded a $50 million contract to produce less costly treatments, but moves by major suppliers might undercut the initiative before any new product emerges.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Ryan
item.media:credit: Amber Ford for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some eight million Americans with diabetes, including about one million Californians, need insulin.

item.title: Could This Be New York City’s Least Snowy Winter in Recorded History?
item.description: Just two inches so far, and a tie for the second-mildest winter.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Paris
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Central Park snowman on Feb. 28. It didn’t last long.

item.title: Pineapple and Ham Belong Together
item.description: On the Easter table and, yes, on pizza, these smart, flavorful tweaks make the retro combination even better.
item.dc:creator: Eric Kim
item.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.
item.media:description: Baking a bone-in half ham, cut side down in a lagoon of pineapple juice, means the sweet juice infuses the pork as the ham releases some of its saltiness into the liquid.

item.title: Today’s Wordle Review: March 23, 2023
item.description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
item.dc:creator: Sabaa Tahir
